text: This poem draft really took it out of me. I'm writing about the depiction of Dr. Dixon, an autistic surgeon on Grey's Anatomy.
I don't know why "researching the DSM 5 criteria for ASD to use in a poem" and "listening to the Interstellar score" fit together so well but they do.
@aGirlCalledChar Thank you! I've been agonizing over this for a year, but simultaneously saying how I would like to meet more autistic people in my town, so...
After spending a year on their mailing list, I have finally signed up for the autistic-led support group in my town. They're having an online meeting tonight. Wish me luck!

Is there such a thing as ADHD / music twitter? Because hello I would like to connect. 

#ADHD #ADHDTwitter

Leaving the degree was still absolutely the right choice and I am happy where I am now, but oh my god. Years of feeling inferior to my classmates and thinking I just didn't have what it takes because I didn't pick up on things as easily as they did.

It turns out *deep breath*. That I don't actually suck at sight-reading music. Or learning new pieces. I just had. UNMEDICATED ADHD. 

I am having a minor identity crisis and lowkey want to scream. Can you imagine how much easier my music degree could have been?

Why is it that student services plays dead until I remind them that they indeed promised to set up a meeting or support me in some other  way? 

I'm half-way through my degree and have had no help from them whatsoever.

On the downside, I am accustomed to having full, busy days and just falling into bed exhausted at night. Now, I have most things done by mid-afternoon. More time to notice that I am actually pretty depressed (which is why I keep so busy).

Day four on ADHD Meds. Upped the dosage this morning. I seem to have a lot more time all of a sudden. Even though I have the same amount of time. Being able to initiate tasks saves so much time and energy.

One thing I am really really hoping for with the adhd meds is that they might allow me to read again. Fiction, academic papers, I don't care what. Just let me be focused enough to read.

Day 2 on ADHD Meds: My executive function is a lot better. When I realise I want/need to do something, it becomes much easier to do the thing right away. Like making a snack or washing dishes. I like it.

First day on ADHD meds, folks! At first I didn't think anything was happening (they took about 2 hours to kick in), but I've noticed I am able to remember things. Like what I put on my to do list this morning. And I'm way less overstimulated by the noise outside.

Now that I'm back at uni, I get misgendered more (bc I'm interacting with more people), so these questions keep coming up. 

I'm getting really sick of hearing "Oh sorry, you're the first person with these pronouns I've met. It's really hard."
Similarly, if someone misgenders me, I correct them, and they apologise, I really don't want to say it's okay. Because it doesn't feel okay.
I've been wondering lately. If someone misgenders me, I correct them and they then use the right pronoun, I don't have to thank them, right? Because I really don't want to.
@PolyamorKitten Ganz genau. Es wäre schön, einfach existieren zu können ohne mich zu fragen, wie fremde Menschen mich heute einordnen werden (und zwangsläufig falsch liegen).

Hey, @HKHSPod I'm just listening to your episode on Unpregnant and I want to point out that folks of all genders need access to abortions. Men and nonbinary folks can get pregnant. So you're right, it's not just a women's issue, but in more ways than you mentioned :)

Still have to do the hallways and the kitchen, but I'm taking a break for lunch. 

Doing it all in one day costs me a lot of energy, but works better for me than doing a little bit at a time. I struggle with switching tasks anyway and cleaning always seems daunting.
I keep getting sidetracked, but that's okay. I've given myself all day to do this.
Very much in keeping with my Adhd brain, I totally forgot I was timing tasks. But I have a vague idea of how long it took to do the bathroom.

- having my cleaning supplies in places that are easy to access, even if it doesn't look as nice
-breaks
- mitigating sensory distress with headphones, gloves, wearing shoes etc
- if you have one, plan a chore you actually look forward to (mine is organising)

General strategies: 
- a high stakes audio drama or very interesting podcast with facts (like @ologies)
- timing myself, but not rushing. That way I know how long things actually take me. I always overestimate.
- list of what needs to be done and how often (still working on that)
I really struggle with cleaning sometimes, but my strategies are working today, so I think I'll share them as I go. #adhdtwitter #ActuallyAutistic

I got another translation offer and this one I'd also read and record for their audioguide. 

The problem: It's an incredibly triggering subject (I didn't know this before the offer came. Just opened the document and now I feel sick).

I made a weekly study plan for myself. It‘s beautiful. But this list of tasks feels like it‘s going to break me every week. 

I want to say „This is boring, but I have to do it so I‘ll just do it now“. But my brain doesn‘t let me do that. F*ck.

And then you think about how there will be a list like that every week until Christmas. And then you start crying and feeling inadequate. 

These are the moments when I best understand my own desire for an ADHD assessment. My brain doesn't work in the way these tasks are set.

That feeling when you get a list of tasks to complete for the week and the estimated time it will take you is 2 hours. But your brain is already overwhelmed with all the detail and the sentences blurr together and you know it's going to take you way more time.

@gravitron_ The funny part about this is that I’m dressed and pretty much ready to go. But I want to get a coffee and I am not ready to speak to people today. That’s what’s stopping me. Going now though. Just a tiny little walk.
Executive dysfunction is so bad today I might cry. I’ve been trying to go for a walk for two hours now.

Now that I'm going to get assessed for ADHD, I'm realising that I'm not bad at life. My brain just needs assistance. All the strategies I've put in place aren't enough to keep me afloat anymore, and it's really hard to wait for the support I would've needed 10 years ago.

I can't do that anymore. It wasn't sustainable. I'm not getting stuff done even though I desperately want to. I pride myself on being organised and reliable. On achieving things and "going somewhere in life". But none of that is happening anymore.

There is this enormous barrier of executive dysfunction that is with me whatever I do. I thrived in school and uni because within these frameworks, there was enough structure and pressure to force my brain to work. I could motivate myself through fear (which was not healthy).

I always tell myself that I *could* do the things I am not doing if only I was better at life. 

Now I'm sitting here, and I WANT to work on my podcast. I really do. 

But I can't. I can't write, I can't edit my podcast. My brain is not letting me and I can't explain it.

What do y‘all pack when you leave the house? I want to know.

#WhatsInYourBackpack https://t.co/MghulYteGA

-different books for different situations

-assorted fidgets

- essential oils or lemon sweets for dissociation

- snacks because I forget to eat

- a big water bottle

- a jacket or cardigan 

- a head covering bc my hair gives me sensory overload

I could go on.

-three different pairs of headphones (ear defenders, in-ear, and over-ear) to be used in different kinds of situations

-silicone ear plugs to reduce the impact of painful noises

-my planner/journal and pens in case I need to write anything down

Yesterday my dad asked me why my backpack is so heavy. It‘s a great question. I often wish my backpack was less heavy. But as it is, I need to carry a bunch of things around to make the world more accessible to me. 

Here are some examples: (thread)

If I don‘t hold myself accountable, I won‘t do it, so: 
I will call my dentist tomorrow morning and tell them my tooth hurts and make an appointment. 

And then I will reschedule my journey accordingly. 

I am scared. Anxiety sucks so much sometimes.

I really need to do this bc the tooth thing isn‘t going to get better if I ignore it. It might just be pain from clenching my jaw, but I need to know for sure. 

It‘s just that I‘m really scared and thus scared to schedule an appointment.

This may seem trivial, but I need support with doing a thing: 
I need to book a dentist appointment and ask for an x-ray on a tooth. And when I‘ve done that I need to reschedule my journey back to Leipzig. 

I would absolutely love some encouraging comments and gifs.

@joefishthomas School was *a lot*
Me, writing this: I hope people relate and like this so i can feel validation.

I only know two modes: unsustainable productivity and high achievements so I can gain praise through academic success, and complete burnout (which has been my state for... a while). I‘m only now starting to unlearn this. No more insights, just sighs and omnipresent exhaustion.

I was a „gifted kid“ (and an undiagnosed autistic kid), and I was different enough to get bullied for it, but not „gifted“ enough to be top of the class in everything. Which means I overworked myself from the age of 12 to the age of 23 to compensate.

When I left my music degree, I lost that tool. I was hurting too much to keep practicing and I didn‘t know how to keep it up without the pressure of lessons and recitals. And now I don‘t know how to get back there again.

I miss the feeling of having a solid technique and feeling the strength of my hands and arms. I miss having a repertoire and a teacher to ask questions. I miss feeling the music. Finding out I‘m autistic meant finding out that music was how I regulated my emotions as a child.

There‘s a kind of grief I carry around with me all the time and it‘s the grief of having practiced piano almost every day for more than ten years only to sit down in front of the piano every couple of weeks now and struggling so much to learn even one bar of music.

I‘d take some sheet music, play for a while, not play for weeks, then take a new piece. It was frustrating, but essentially I was practicing my sight-reading for the first time ever. It‘s so neat to discover that I was still learning even though I thought I was not.

I finally found a piece that I am motivated to learn and that will make me want to practice. I sat down to start playing and sight-read the first two pages. I‘ve always been awful at sight-reading. Absolutely terrible. But for months, this is what I‘d been doing.

Story time. I‘ve been pretty hard on myself for not learning new piano pieces since I started playing again (I took a long break after deciding not to finish my music teaching degree), but the other day I made a discovery.

In conclusion: I was so gay all my life and had no idea.

I subconsciously picked my crushes that way until I was 20 years old. That was when I fell head over heels in love with a woman and was completely overwhelmed because I had no idea crushes could be like that. You live and you learn.

In primary school, I knew I was supposed to have a crush on some boy. So I thought about all the boys in my class and settled on the smart boy who I was always competing with academically. I now know I just really wanted to be his friend (we did become friends in highschool).

Good morning. Remember how I thought Team Jacob and Team Edward was about who was hotter and not who was the better partner for Bella? And how misunderstanding that was a great pointer that you were gay? Well, I discovered yesterday that that is how my crushes worked in school.

Me: I'm neurodivergent? Do I have special interests?
Brain: Yes. 
Me: Ooh what are they?
Brain: Frozen. 
Me: What?
Brain: The Frozen franchise. You will think about it every day for over 3 years. 
Me: ... 
Brain: Let it go.
